docs.description: What is the Accord Project?

docs.title: FAQ
docs.description: Accord Project Frequently asked Questions

docs.title: Smart Legal Contracts
docs.description: A Smart Legal Contract is a human-readable and machine-readable agreement that is digital, consisting of natural language and computable components.

docs.title: Accord Project Templates
docs.description: An Accord Project template ties legal text to computer code. It is composed of three elements:

docs.title: Online Tour
docs.description: To get an better acquainted with Accord Project templates, the easiest way is through the online Template Studio editor.

docs.title: Ergo: A Tutorial
docs.description: Overview of Accord

docs.title: A Healthy Clause
docs.description: Eat Apples!

docs.title: Advanced Expressions
docs.description: Match

docs.title: Complex Values & Types
docs.description: So far we only considered atomic values and types, such as string values or integers, which are not sufficient for most contracts. In Ergo, values and types are based on the Concerto Modeling (often referred to as CTO models after the .cto file extension). This provides a rich vocabulary to define the parameters of your contract, the information associated to contract participants, the structure of contract obligation, etc.

docs.title: Declarations
docs.description: Now that we have values, types, expressions and statements available, we can start writing more complex Ergo logic using by declaring functions, clauses and contracts.

docs.title: Ergo Overview
docs.description: Language Goals

docs.title: Modules
docs.description: Finally, we can place multiple Ergo declarations (functions, contracts, etc) into a library so it can be shared with other developers.

docs.title: Simple Expressions
docs.description: Literal values

docs.title: Introducing Types
docs.description: We have so far talked about types only informally. When we wrote earlier:

docs.title: Statements
docs.description: A clause's body is composed of statements. Statements are a special kind of expression which can manipulate the contract state and emit obligations. Unlike other expressions they may return a response or an error.

docs.title: CiceroMark
docs.description: CiceroMark is an extension to CommonMark used to write the text in Accord Project contracts. The extension is limited in scope, and designed to help with parsing clauses inside contracts and the result of formulas.

docs.title: CommonMark
docs.description: The following CommonMark guide is non normative, but included for convenience. For a more detailed introduction we refer the reader the CommonMark Webpage and Specification.

docs.title: Preliminaries
docs.description: Markdown & CommonMark

docs.title: TemplateMark
docs.description: TemplateMark is an extension to CommonMark used to write the text in Accord Project templates. The extension includes new markdown for variables, inline and container elements of the markdown and template formulas.

docs.title: Using the API
docs.description: Install the Core Library

docs.title: Classes
docs.description: Concepts

docs.title: Concerto Overview
docs.description: Principles

docs.title: Decorators
docs.description: Model elements may have arbitrary decorators (aka annotations) placed on them. These are available via API and can be useful for tools to extend the model. Accord Project decorators are defined in the Decorators Reference.

docs.title: Enumerations
docs.description: Enumerations are used to capture lists of domain values.

docs.title: Namespaces
docs.description: Each Concerto file starts with the name of a single namespace, which contains the base definitions of asset, event, participant and transaction. All definitions within a single file belong to the same namespace.

docs.title: Properties
docs.description: Class declarations contain properties. Each property has a type which can either be a type defined in the same namespace, an imported type, or a primitive type.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.description: A relationship in Concerto Modeling Language (CML) is a tuple composed of:

docs.description: Modules

docs.title: Command Line
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/cicero-cli npm package to access the Cicero command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the cicero command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: Template Testing
docs.description: Cicero uses Cucumber for writing template tests, which provides a human readable syntax.

docs.title: Node.js API
docs.description: concerto-core

docs.title: Command Line
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/concerto-cli npm package to access the Concerto command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the concerto command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: Decorators
docs.description: Decorators are used to add metadata to Concerto model elements, typically to control how variables are edited, printed or transformed.

docs.title: Node.js API
docs.description: Classes

docs.title: Command Line
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/ergo-cli npm package to access the Ergo command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the ergo command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: Read-Eval-Print Loop
docs.description: ergotop is a convenient tool to try-out Ergo contracts in an interactive way. You can write commands, or expressions and see the result. It is often called the Ergo REPL, for read-eval-print-loop, since it literally: reads your input Ergo from the command-line, evaluates it, prints the result and loops back to read your next input.

docs.title: Specification
docs.description: Lexical Conventions

docs.title: Standard Library
docs.description: The following libraries are provided with the Ergo compiler.

docs.title: Errors
docs.description: As much as possible, errors returned by all projects (notably Cicero and the Ergo compiler) are normalized and categorized in order to facilitate handling of those error by the application code. Those errors are raised as JavaScript exceptions.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.description: Variable

docs.title: Command Line
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/markdown-cli npm package to access the Markdown Transform command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the markus command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: 0.13 to 0.20
docs.description: Much has changed in the 0.20 release. This guide provides step-by-step instructions to port your Accord Project templates from version 0.13 or earlier to version 0.20.

docs.title: 0.20 to 0.21
docs.description: The main change between the 0.20 release and the 0.21 release is the new markdown syntax and parser infrastructure based on markdown-it. While most templates designed for 0.20 should still work on 0.21 some changes might be needed to the contract or template text to account for this new syntax.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: Accord Project publishes React user interface components for use in web applications. Please refer to the web-components project on GitHub for detailed usage instructions.

docs.title: Hello World Template
docs.description: Once you have installed Cicero, you can try it on an existing Accord Project template. This explains how to create an instance of that template and how to run the contract logic.

docs.title: Install Cicero
docs.description: To experiment with Accord Project, you can install the Cicero command-line. This will let you author, validate, and run Accord Project templates on your own machine.

docs.title: Resources
docs.description: Accord Project Resources

docs.title: Template Generator
docs.description: Now that you have executed an existing template, let's create a new template from scratch. To facilitate the creation of new templates, Cicero comes with a template generator.

docs.title: With Hyperledger Fabric
docs.description: Hyperledger Fabric 2.2

docs.title: Template Library
docs.description: This tutorial explains how to get access, and contribute, to all of the public templates available as part of the the Accord Project Template Library.

docs.title: With Node.js
docs.description: Cicero Node.js API

docs.title: With Template Studio
docs.description: This tutorial will walk you through the steps of editing a clause template in Template Studio.

docs.title: Templates Deep Dive
docs.description: In the Getting Started section, we learned how to use the existing helloworld@0.13.0.cta template archive. Here we take a look inside that archive to understand the structure of Accord Project templates.

docs.title: With VS Code
docs.description: Cicero comes with a VS Code extension for easier development and testing. It includes support for syntax highlighting, allows you to test your template (contract parsing and logic) and to create template archives directly within VS Code.

docs.title: How to Use a Template
docs.description: The simplest way to work with an Accord Project template is through the Cicero command line interface (CLI). In this tutorial, we explain how to download an existing Accord Project template, create an instance of that template and how to execute the contract logic.

docs.title: Example: Late Delivery Clause
docs.description: In the rest of this specification, we will use the Late Delivery And Penalty legal clause as an example. It is a common clause in a legal contract related to the delivery of good or services, and in some circumstances may be amenable to automation.

docs.title: Command Line
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/ergo-cli npm package to access the Ergo command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the ergo command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: Read-Eval-Print Loop
docs.description: ergotop is a convenient tool to try-out Ergo contracts in an interactive way. You can write commands, or expressions and see the result. It is often called the Ergo REPL, for read-eval-print-loop, since it literally: reads your input Ergo from the command-line, evaluates it, prints the result and loops back to read your next input.

docs.title: Specification
docs.description: Lexical Conventions

docs.title: Standard Library
docs.description: The following libraries are provided with the Ergo compiler.

docs.title: Errors Reference
docs.description: As much as possible, errors returned by Cicero or the Ergo compiler are normalized and categorized in order to facilitate handling of those error by the application code. Those errors are raised in Cicero as JavaScript exceptions.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.description: Variable

docs.title: Ergo Language Reference
docs.description: Lexical Conventions

docs.title: Ergo Compiler
docs.description: A large part of the Ergo compiler is written as a Coq specification

docs.title: Ergo Standard Library
docs.description: The following libraries are provided with the Ergo compiler.

docs.title: Markup Reference
docs.description: Markup Syntax

docs.title: Command Line
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/markdown-cli npm package to access the Markdown Transform command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the markus command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: 0.13 to 0.20
docs.description: Much has changed in the new 0.20 release. This guide provides step-by-step instructions to port your Accord Project templates from version 0.13 or earlier to version 0.20.

docs.title: 0.20 to 0.21
docs.description: The main change between the 0.20 release and the 0.21 release is the new markdown syntax and parser infrastructure based on markdown-it. While most templates designed for 0.20 should still work on 0.21 some changes might be needed to the contract or template text to account for this new syntax.

docs.title: Testing Reference
docs.description: Cicero uses Cucumber for writing template tests, which provides a human readable syntax.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: Accord Project publishes React user interface components for use in web applications. Please refer to the web-components project on GitHub for detailed usage instructions.

docs.title: Concepts and High-level Architecture
docs.description: Overview

docs.title: Example: Late Delivery Clause
docs.description: In the rest of this specification, we will use the Late Delivery And Penalty legal clause as an example. It is a common clause in a legal contract related to the delivery of good or services, and in some circumstances may be amenable to automation.

docs.title: Contract Execution
docs.description: Interfacing the Template with the Outside World

docs.title: Template Instantiation
docs.description: Contract

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: This specification defines the structure of Accord Project Templates: legally enforceable natural language text that is bound to executable business logic.

docs.title: Packaging
docs.description: The artifacts that define a template are:

docs.title: Template Structure
docs.description: An Accord Project template is composed of three elements:

docs.title: Hello World Template
docs.description: Once you have installed Cicero, you can try it on an existing Accord Project template. This explains how to create an instance of that template and how to run the contract logic.

docs.title: Install Cicero
docs.description: To experience the full power of Accord Project, you should install the Cicero command-line tools. This will let you author, validate, and run Accord Project templates on your own machine.

docs.title: Resources
docs.description: Accord Project Resources

docs.title: Online Tour
docs.description: To get an better acquainted with Accord Project templates, the easiest way is through the online Template Studio editor.

docs.title: Template Generator
docs.description: Now that you have executed an existing template, let's create a new template from scratch. To facilitate the creation of new templates, Cicero comes with a template generator.

docs.title: Deploying on Hyperledger Fabric
docs.description: Hyperledger Fabric 1.3

docs.title: Editing a Late Delivery Clause
docs.description: This tutorial will walk you through the steps of authoring a clause template in Template Studio.

docs.title: Template Library
docs.description: This tutorial explains how to get access, and contribute, to all of the public templates available as part of the the Accord Project Template Library.

docs.title: Working with Node.js
docs.description: Cicero Node.js API

docs.title: With Template Studio
docs.description: This tutorial will walk you through the steps of editing a clause template in Template Studio.

docs.title: Templates Deep Dive
docs.description: In the Getting Started section, we learned how to use the existing helloworld@0.12.0.cta template archive. Here we take a look inside that archive to understand the structure of Accord Project templates.

docs.title: With VS Code
docs.description: Cicero comes with a VS Code extension for easier development and testing. It includes support for syntax highlighting, allows you to test your template (contract parsing and logic) and to create template archives directly within VS Code.

docs.title: Getting Started with Accord Project
docs.description: What is Accord Project?

docs.title: FAQ
docs.description: Accord Project Frequently asked Questions

docs.title: Installation
docs.description: To start working on your own Accord Project templates, you should install the Cicero command-line tools. This will let you author, parse, and execute Accord Project templates.

docs.title: Standard Models
docs.description: Accord Project maintains an Open Source Models Repository containing standard reusable data models that you can import and use within your Smart Legal Contract Cicero templates and in your Ergo logic.

docs.title: Learning Resources
docs.description: Accord Project Resources

docs.title: Smart Legal Contracts
docs.description: A Smart Legal Contract is a human-readable and machine-readable agreement that is digital, consisting of natural language and computable components.

docs.title: Template Studio
docs.description: Template Studio lets you create, edit and test legal clause or contract templates built with the Accord Project.

docs.title: Accord Project Templates
docs.description: An Accord Project template ties legal text to computer code. It is composed of three elements:

docs.title: Open Source Templates
docs.description: Accord Project maintains an Open Source Templates Library of legal clauses and contracts that conform to the Accord Project template specification.

docs.title: Developers Tools
docs.description: Several tools are available in order to help you develop your own smart legal templates.

docs.title: Online Tour
docs.description: To get an better acquainted with Accord Project templates, the easiest way is through the online Template Studio editor.

docs.title: Deploying on Hyperledger Fabric
docs.description: Hyperledger Fabric 1.3

docs.title: Authoring in Template Studio
docs.description: This tutorial will walk you through the steps of authoring a clause template in Template Studio.

docs.description: Cicero Node.js API

docs.title: Creating a New Template
docs.description: Now that you have executed an existing template, let's create a new template.

docs.title: Publishing a Template
docs.description: This tutorial explains how to contribute a new template to the Accord Project Template Library.

docs.title: Take a Look Inside
docs.description: Now that you have executed an existing template in archive form, let us look inside that archive to understand the structure of that template.

docs.title: How to Use a Template
docs.description: The simplest way to work with an Accord Project template is through the Cicero command line interface (CLI). In this tutorial, we explain how to download an existing Accord Project template, create an instance of that template and how to execute the contract logic.

docs.title: Cicero API
docs.description: Modules

docs.title: Cicero CLI
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/cicero-cli npm package to access the Cicero command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the cicero command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: Ergo API
docs.description: Classes

docs.title: Ergo CLI
docs.description: To install the Ergo command-line interface (CLI):

docs.title: Ergo: A Tutorial
docs.description: Overview of Accord

docs.title: A Healthy Clause
docs.description: Eat Apples!

docs.title: Advanced Expressions
docs.description: Match

docs.title: Complex Values & Types
docs.description: So far we only considered atomic values and types, such as string values or integers, which are not sufficient for most contracts. In Ergo, values and types are based on the Composer Concerto Modeling Language (often referred to as CTO files). This provides a rich vocabulary to define the parameters of your contract, the information associated to contract participants, the structure of contract obligation, etc.

docs.title: Declarations
docs.description: Now that we have values, types, expressions and statements available, we can start writing more complex Ergo logic using by declaring functions, clauses and contracts.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: Language Goals

docs.title: Modularity
docs.description: Finally, we can place multiple Ergo declarations (functions, contracts, etc) into a library so it can be shared with other developers.

docs.title: Simple Expressions
docs.description: Literal values

docs.title: Introducing Types
docs.description: We have so far talked about types only informally. When we wrote earlier:

docs.title: Statements
docs.description: A clause's body is composed of statements. Statements are a special kind of expression which can manipulate the contract state and emit obligations. Unlike other expressions they may return a response or an error.

docs.title: CiceroMark
docs.description: CiceroMark is an extension to CommonMark used to write the text in Accord Project contracts. The extension is limited in scope, and designed to help with parsing clauses inside contracts and the result of formulas.

docs.title: CommonMark
docs.description: The following CommonMark guide is non normative, but included for convenience. For a more detailed introduction we refer the reader the CommonMark Webpage and Specification.

docs.title: Preliminaries
docs.description: Markdown & CommonMark

docs.title: TemplateMark
docs.description: TemplateMark is an extension to CommonMark used to write the text in Accord Project templates. The extension includes new markdown for variables, inline and container elements of the markdown and template formulas.

docs.title: Using the API
docs.description: Install the Core Library

docs.title: Classes
docs.description: Concepts

docs.title: Concerto Overview
docs.description: Principles

docs.title: Decorators
docs.description: Model elements may have arbitrary decorators (aka annotations) placed on them. These are available via API and can be useful for tools to extend the model. Accord Project decorators are defined in the Decorators Reference.

docs.title: Enumerations
docs.description: Enumerations are used to capture lists of domain values.

docs.title: Namespaces
docs.description: Each Concerto file starts with the name of a single namespace, which contains the base definitions of asset, event, participant and transaction. All definitions within a single file belong to the same namespace.

docs.title: Properties
docs.description: Class declarations contain properties. Each property has a type which can either be a type defined in the same namespace, an imported type, or a primitive type.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.description: A relationship in Concerto Modeling Language (CML) is a tuple composed of:

docs.title: Template Testing
docs.description: Cicero uses Cucumber for writing template tests, which provides a human readable syntax.

docs.title: Node.js API
docs.description: concerto-core

docs.title: Command Line
docs.description: Install the @accordproject/concerto-cli npm package to access the Concerto command line interface (CLI). After installation you can use the concerto command and its sub-commands as described below.

docs.title: Decorators
docs.description: Decorators are used to add metadata to Concerto model elements, typically to control how variables are edited, printed or transformed.
